page.title: 13THE TYNE VALLEY RAILWAY
page.content: The Tyne Valley Railway which runs through Wylam was the first line to be built across Britain. Wylam Station is one of the oldest passenger stations in the World and is still in regular use. It was built soon after the opening of the Blaydon-Hexham line in 1835. Unfortunately the Stationmaster's house at Wylam is not in use anymore because of an open station system. On the 9th of June 1781 George Stephenson Wylam's most famous son was born in a small cottage half a mile east of the village now owned by The National Trust. He was known to have proved the locomotive to be a practical success for railway traffic and many of his exhibits can be seen at Wylam Railway Museum in the Falcon Centre.
